newsitem.title: USA: Ready for reform? Chicago's aldermen say they are.
newsitem.headline: Ready for reform? Chicago's aldermen say they are.

text.p: Chicago's city council, which runs a city once described as not ready for reform, embarked on a new ethical era Thursday.
The city's aldermen voted 40-9 on Wednesday in favour of an ordinance granting Mayor Richard Daley the power to appoint an ethics board to oversee the 50 members of the city council.
It was the election of Daley's father as mayor in 1955 that prompted Alderman Paddy Bauler to pronounce: "Chicago ain't ready for reform."

Alderman Ed Smith quipped that so many members of the council had been jailed over the years -- 20 in the past 21 years by one count -- that the council would have to meet at the federal prison in Wisconsin to obtain a quorum.
A previous council-passed ethics ordinance had exempted the aldermen, but this one would require closer record-keeping of campaign contributions, gifts, and staff workers.

Among those voting for the ethics ordinance was 21st Ward Alderman Jesse Evans, who awaits sentencing for accepting bribes from a waste hauler who actually was an undercover informer in the local U.S. Attorney's "Silver Shovel" sting operation.
Federal indictments governing people earning salaries for phantom jobs under the "Haunted Hall" probe have ensnared several other aldermen.
